The Kings of the Road Ken W. Purdy A few black-and-white photographs. 256 pages. Little, Brown & Company, 1952.

Few car books bear rereading. For marque histories and learned studies, a single pass usually suffices before they are shelved for reference, while coffee-table tomes often have text so thin they're better left unread.

An exception to the rule is Ken W. Purdy's ''Kings of the Road,'' from 1952. In print for an amazing 17 years, it served as early education for more than a generation of enthusiasts, and it still delights today.

The book covers the usual prewar icons -- Bugatti, Rolls-Royce, Mercedes-Benz and Duesenberg -- as well as Mr. Purdy's favorite Mercer Raceabout. Le Mans, the Indianapolis 500 and the Vanderbilt Cup races rate chapters, as does ''The Flying Mantuan,'' the great driver Tazio Nuvolari. A chapter on front-wheel drive puts a little-known pioneer, J. Walter Christie, on an equal footing with E. L. Cord and André Citroën; the Stanley twins share the spotlight in the chapter on steam cars.

This is not a definitive history, and it has its share of errors, though many of them were conventional wisdom at publication. The author's style is plain, yet pithy. The owner of a Bugatti ''becomes its willing slave for life,'' and the Mercer's attraction ''derives from its starkness.''
Copies of the book are plentiful on the used market, often inexpensive and much more satisfying than a retreaded Porsche potboiler.
